headline.main: Demonstrators Find That the Web Is a Powerful Tool

lead_paragraph: It was just before Jodie Hemerda set off a family feud by announcing her opposition to the United States bombing in Afghanistan that she began scouring the Internet for others who shared her views. She was not having much success in her hometown, Parker, Colo., where only the rare minivan does not fly an American flag. Rather than risk alienating the other mothers in the neighborhood, Ms. Hemerda, 30, has refrained from voicing her antiwar sentiments as they shuttle the children to and from school.
abstract: Many of small and scattered group of Americans who disapprove of Bush administration's bombing of Afghanistan as response to Sept 11 terrorist attacks are finding Internet powerful tool for reaching out to other dissenters and forming movement; first generation of Internet activists may be spreading their message farther and faster than their predecessors in earlier, more popular political protests; photo (M)
